comments: Finally 8 teams playoffs, ESL 6 team bracket is so shit.

Edit: Also, quite important change for teams that plans to rebuild, eg. someone like Falcons who loses their core and thus far ranking points, and now have to rely on wildcard invites and qualifiers. Since it gives them more to play
Headliner here is the Buenos Aires event has been moved to Cluj-Napoca
PGL doing more than ESL and BLAST have in 4 years of duopoly.

Closed Qualifiers
SA/NA/EUR:

Total Teams: 32

8 teams from Open Qualifiers.

24 teams invited based on VRS rankings.

Asia:

16 teams from Open Qualifiers.

16 teams invited based on VRS rankings.

Round 1

32 teams divided into 4 groups of 8.

Each group plays a Double Elimination (DE) bracket, with matches in Best-of-3 (BO3) format.

The 1st-place team from each group advances to Round 2.

Round 2

4 teams compete in a Single Elimination (SE) bracket.

Matches are Best-of-3 (BO3), with the Grand Final being Best-of-5 (BO5).
The winner advances to the Main Event.

With the addition of qualifiers to the tournaments, invitations to the Main Tournament will be distributed as follows:

12 invites based on VRS

1 team from SA Closed Qualifiers

1 team from NA Closed Qualifiers

1 team from EUR Closed Qualifiers

1 team from Asia Closed Qualifiers

The Language explanation offered by escharts on that article sounds unconvincing. It's just a category distinction and categories can & do exist for all sorts of things. Food, eSports, memes, casual talk, Travel, Li Ziqi type content, etc etc. This is trivial for online platforms to integrate in their access/interaction flow. 

The actual answer is in simple terms, "*Proprietary Data*".

> This metric (Heat Score) includes several variables, and no one, except the developers themselves, can name their exact number.

Chinese platforms simply do not share publicly that **1** vector (Concurrent Live Spectators) in this Heat Score equation is & what its weightage is in that equation.

Chinese internet scene is ruthless competition and this sort of data in many cases has competitive edge cases for their businesses.

Though companies that partner with them may & likely will have access to this data, broken down by individual vectors. Valve possibly does have these numbers (actual CS scene estimate in China).  

Additionally this sort of data breakdown & news announcement about it by the Platforms on certain ocassions/events is likely present/discussed on Chinese internet. We just aren't privy to that because of the Language barrier in accessing their Internet space.

Chinese Internet scene isn't some backwater, it's at the leading edge of where this domain is. It indeed has massive scale, we're just haggling over how massive, which for CS events like Majors becomes, is it 4 Million Chinese watching or is it 1.5 Million.

Because for sure as hell it ain't like 50,000. That simply doesn't work and pass the smell test. 

As for this post. Pre-2024 PW Majors and this Major's viewership for RoW+Asian combined tally is likely going to see an increase. 

This would be a simply function of statistical scale. Asia is much bigger and bulk of it is sleeping when other Majors in Europe/NA happen. Meaning the degree by which numbers will rise in Asia will be massively higher in relative terms than the degree by which it can fall in Europe & NA due to raw underlying scale.
